The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". The Congress acknowledges that Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are rapidly increasing in the U.S., affecting all demographics. The current rate of autism is 1 in 150, with a new case diagnosed every 20 minutes. The financial burden of autism on the nation exceeds $35 billion annually. The epidemic of autism is rapidly increasing in the U.S., with a new case diagnosed every 20 minutes. The financial burden exceeds $35 billion annually, impacting various sectors like education, labor, housing, and healthcare. This condition could potentially deprive the nation of future talent in military, industrial, medical, and scientific fields. The autism epidemic is a growing concern in the U.S., with a new case diagnosed every 20 minutes. This could potentially impact future talent in military, industrial, medical, and scientific fields. Despite the urgency of autism spectrum disorders, research funding is lacking, with autism receiving less than 5 percent of federal research funding for childhood diseases. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated nearly $1 billion for autism research, including studies on environmental factors, treatments, and early identification services. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated $1 billion for autism research, focusing on environmental factors, treatments, and early identification services. A White House Conference on Autism aims to advance scientific study and analysis of cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. A White House Conference on Autism aims to advance scientific study and analysis of cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF THE CONFERENCE. The President must call the White House Conference on Autism by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations on combating autism in the US. The Secretaries of Health, Education, and Housing will plan and convene the Conference to galvanize a national effort to find the causes of autism. The Co-chairs will plan and convene the Conference with the Surgeon General to address the causes of autism, find solutions for autistic individuals and families, conduct research on potential triggers, and initiate a national dialogue on lifelong challenges faced by autistic children and their families. The comprehensive research agenda includes exploring potential environmental triggers for autism, bringing together parents and leaders in education and social services for a national dialogue, highlighting innovative programs for autistic individuals, and reviewing existing legislation and programs for autism research services at various levels of government. The legislation aims to review and improve existing programs for autistic individuals at federal, state, and local levels to enhance their health and well-being. SEC. 4. POLICY COMMITTEE; RELATED COMMITTEES. Established by June 30, 2009, the Policy Committee consists of 17 members selected by the President and House appointees. Members include officers or employees of the United States and individuals with experience in addressing autism spectrum disorders. The Policy Committee, established by June 30, 2009, consists of 17 members selected by the President and House appointees. House appointees include two members selected by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and two members selected by the minority leader. Senate appointees include two members selected by the majority leader of the Senate. The Policy Committee, established by June 30, 2009, consists of 17 members selected by the President and House appointees. Senate appointees include two members selected by the majority leader of the Senate, with 50 percent drawn from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia, including a parent or legal guardian of individuals with autism or other pervasive developmental disorders. Senate appointees include two members selected by the majority leader of the Senate, with 50 percent drawn from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia. 50 percent of the members must have special qualifications, including knowledge about autism intervention programs, educational and housing needs of individuals with autism. Senate appointees include two members selected by the majority leader of the Senate, with 50 percent drawn from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia. The committee members must have special qualifications, including knowledge about autism intervention programs, educational and housing needs of individuals with autism. Specifically, members must be knowledgeable about programs designed for autism education, housing, law enforcement training for individuals with autism, and environmental or toxic exposure related to autism development. The Policy Committee acts by majority vote, with a quorum required for conducting business. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, acts by majority vote with a quorum required for business. Duties include meetings, hearings, and working sessions to address autism-related issues such as environmental or toxic exposure. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, meets to make recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference, propose an agenda, select delegates, and establish an executive committee. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, meets to make recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference, propose an agenda, select delegates, and establish an executive committee. Additionally, the Policy Committee is responsible for establishing the number of delegates to be selected and an executive committee consisting of 3 members to work with the delegates. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES.

The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds in the field of autism and neurodevelopmental disorders, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and members of the public affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States.

SEC. 6. CONFERENCE ADMINISTRATION. In administering this section, the Cochairs shall provide notice to all Policy Committee members of meetings, request cooperation from other Federal departments, make proposed agendas available for public comment, and provide necessary background materials for delegates. The Policy Committee, prepared by the Cochairs, will address major autism issues for the Conference. They will provide necessary background materials and hire additional personnel as needed. Cochairs must ensure duties are carried out effectively. The Cochairs are responsible for ensuring that appointments are made without regard to classification and pay rates, publishing the agenda in the Federal Register, maintaining a balanced representation of views in personnel appointments, and ensuring recommendations are not influenced by public officials or special interests. The Cochairs ensure appointments are unbiased, maintain balanced representation of views, and prevent influence from public officials or special interests in Conference recommendations. Statistical data on autism spectrum disorders is required before the Conference convenes. The Cochairs may obtain necessary information on autism spectrum disorders through grants or agreements with public agencies or nonprofit organizations for the Conference. They can also accept gifts (cash or in kind) on behalf of the United States to support the implementation of this Act. The Cochairs may accept gifts (cash or in kind) on behalf of the United States to support the implementation of this Act. Gifts can be earmarked for specific purposes and records must be maintained regarding the sources, amounts, and uses of gifts accepted, as well as the recipients of assistance and the amount received by each. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Policy Committee must prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state chief executive officers. States must submit their views on the report within 45 days. A final report, including state executives' views, must be prepared within 6 months of adjournment and submitted to the President and Congress. The Policy Committee must prepare a final report of the Conference, including state executives' views, and publish it in the Federal Register. Recommendations for administrative action and legislation must be transmitted to the President and Congress. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. The Surgeon General must prepare and publish a status report on the implementation of recommendations within 2 years of the Conference adjournment. The Comptroller General must also prepare and publish subsequent status reports every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. These reports will be transmitted to the President and Congress. SEC. 9. DEFINITION OF STATE. The term "State" in this Act refers to several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, or the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization is granted for necessary funds to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated and received as gifts are available for use, except as specified. The United States is obligated to make outlays as provided in appropriations Acts. Funds appropriated for the Act and gifts received shall remain available for 1 year after the Conference adjourns. Unobligated funds after this period shall be returned to the Treasury, unless the Conference is not convened before December 31, 2010. If funds are not used within 1 year after the Conference adjourns, they will be returned to the Treasury. If the Conference is not convened by December 31, 2010, a trust fund will be established for a future Conference on Autism.
